text: I don't think I don't like the word
requirement really in itself and I don't
think that's something like and I don't
really like the word community service
that much either um because I think it
comes with the stigma of it's a
requirement to a lot of students and so
it doesn't seem like something that's
very meaningful or important it's just
like something that you have to do in
order to graduate so um um but I do
think that there needs to be some sort
of requirement in some sense because a
lot of people otherwise wouldn't get
involved but it needs to it needs to
engage the students a lot a lot of
places where where uh schools have uh
students doing volunteer work it's
mindless work they don't have to think
they go and they sit in an office and
they file papers for however many hours
they have to do it in the minute that
they get to the last hour of their
commitment they're out they're done
they're happy and you know that's okay
but it's really that's doing nothing to
build a movement and it's not engaging
the students at all so if anything it
really turns them away from wanting to
get involved with things like this in
the future so I think that you know
students should be given an opportunity
to choose what issues they want to work
on and
um and that's why we always have the
forums and workshops about student
leadership so that they can learn that
historically students have been a huge
part of every single movement that this
country and this world has ever had and
that's not really told in our textbooks
very much you know it's not really
taught to us in school that that's a
fact but it really is and I think when
students see that in the past students
have been so powerful um in movements
and creating social change they're more
likely to stay involved with it now and
especially if they're working within
their communities or communities right
near them on combating issues that
directly affect them um I don't see any
reason why it wouldn't kind of hook on
to somebody you know there are plenty of
people who will fade off and you know
this type of stuff isn't for them and
that's you know that's fine that's
everybody's personal choice but you know
we've seen that the more that we link
these issues to our communities the more
people stay involved and stay
invigorated and want to continue to do
work
